gmd:hierarchyLevelName.gco:CharacterString: Highest level of data collection, from a common set of sensors or instrumentation, usually within the same research project

gmd:title.gmx:Anchor: GT10 - FIA-AlFe from the U.S. GEOTRACES NAT project of the U.S. GEOTRACES program

gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString: Shipboard flow injection analyis (FIA) of dissolved Al and Fe. Dataset Description: <p>Shipboard flow injection analysis (FIA) data of dissolved metals from the GT10 (KN199-04) cruise. Samples were collected using GO-FLO bottles and filtered through 0.2 µm Acropak filters. Concentrations and quality flags are reported for each metal.</p><p><strong>Related files and references:</strong><br />Measures, C.I., J. Yang, and J.A. Resing, J., 1995. Determination of iron in seawater by flow injection analysis using in-line preconcention and spectrophotometric detection, Mar. Chem., 50, 3-12. doi: <a href="http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/0304-4203(95)00022-J" target="_blank">10.1016/0304-4203(95)00022-J</a><br />Resing, J., Measures, C.I., 1994.&nbsp; Fluorometric determination of A1 in seawater by FIA with in-line pre concentration. Anal. Chem. 66, 4105-4111. doi: <a href="http://dx.doi.org/10.1021/ac00094a039" target="_blank">10.1021/ac00094a039</a></p><p>Please note that some US GEOTRACES data may not be final, pending intercalibration results and further analysis. If you are interested in following changes to US GEOTRACES NAT data, there is an RSS feed available via the BCO-DMO <a href="http://www.bco-dmo.org/project/2066">US GEOTRACES project page</a> (scroll down and expand the "Datasets" section).</p> Acquisition Description: <p><strong>Sampling Methods</strong><br />The samples (with the exception of surface samples) were collected for trace metal determinations at 11 stations from the RV Knorr using a custom-built US GEOTRACES trace metal clean rosette consisting of an epoxy painted Al rosette frame containing 24x12 L GO-FLO bottles (Cutter and Bruland, 2012). Immediately after the package was recovered, the tops of the GO-FLO bottles were covered with plastic bags and the bottles were removed from the frame and carried into the US GEOTRACES clean van for sub-sampling. The GO-FLO bottles were pressurized to 10 psi using 0.2 µm-filtered compressed air and samples were filtered through 0.2 µm Acropak filters. All sub-sampling was undertaken in the clean van using rigorous trace metal protocols. Surface samples are from the towed fish surface sampling system.</p><p><strong>Analytical Methods</strong><br /><strong>FIA Sample Preparation</strong>: Samples were drawn into pre-numbered 125 ml PMP bottles after three rinses and were stored in plastic bags in the dark at room temperature before determination which was usually within 12 -36 hours of collection. Prior to determination samples were acidified by the addition of 125 ul sub-boiling distilled 6N HCl (hereinafter 6N HCl) and were microwaved in groups of 4 for 3 minutes in a 900 W microwave oven to achieve a temperature of 60+10 °C. Samples were allowed to cool for at least 1 hour prior to determination. Samples were determined in groups of 8.</p><p><strong>FIA Standards</strong>: Shipboard mixed standards (Al and Fe, Mn) were prepared in the shore-based laboratory by serial dilution of commercial Al, Fe, and Mn standards (BDH Aristar) into distilled water which was acidified with the equivalent of 4 ml sub-boiled 6N HCl.&nbsp; Standards for instrument calibration were prepared daily from filtered seawater by acidifying 1 L of low Fe seawater from a previous cast with 1 ml of 6N HCl and microwaving for 5 minutes to reach a temperature of 60 + 10°C.&nbsp; After 1 hour, 200 + 2 ml of the cooled seawater was added to each of three 250 ml PMP bottles each of which had been rinsed three times with the microwaved seawater and shaken dry. Working standards were prepared by adding 0, +100µL, +200µL spikes of the shipboard mixed standard to these bottles, to yield a standard curve of +28.4nM and +56.81nM for Al, +1.26nM and +2.53nM for Fe, +5.11nM and +10.22nM for Mn. The system blank from the addition of the acid and buffer to samples was determined by double spiking a replicate sample i.e. by adding 2 x 125 ul 6N HCl and 5 ml of sample buffer to the replicate bottle and comparing the resulting signal to the original sample.</p><p><strong>Dissolved Al Concentrations</strong>: Dissolved Al was determined using a Flow Injection Analysis scheme with fluorometric detection. Major components were a Rabbit peristaltic pump, a Dynamax FL-1 fluorometer, a Rainin A/D board and a Macintosh G3 computer running Rainin MacIntegrator v 1.4.3 to log and reduce data. The analytical scheme produces a complex between lumogallion and dissolved Al which when excited at 484 nm produces fluorescence at 552 nm.&nbsp; Detailed description of the methodology is published in Resing and Measures (1994).</p><p>A 3-minute pre-concentration of sample (~9 ml) onto an 8-hydroxyquinoline (8-HQ) resin column yielded a detection limit of 1.02 and a precision of 1.94% at 17.58 nM.</p><p><strong>Dissolved Fe</strong>: Dissolved Fe was determined using a Flow Injection Analysis scheme with spectrophotometric detection (Rainin Dynamax UV-C). Major components were a Rabbit peristaltic pump, a Dynamax FL-1 fluorometer, a Rainin A/D board and a Macintosh G3 computer running Rainin MacIntegrator v 1.4.3 to log and reduce data. The spectrophotometric detection of the iron eluted from the column is achieved through its catalytic effect on the oxidation of N,N-dimethylp-phenylenediamine dihydrochloride (DPD) the oxidised product is measured at 514 nm. Detailed description of the methodology is published in Measures et al (1995).</p><p>A 3-minute pre-concentration of sample (~9 ml) onto an 8-hydroxyquinoline (8-HQ) resin column yielded a detection limit of 0.064 nM and a precision of 3.1%.</p><p><strong>Calculation of FIA data</strong>: Calculation of sample concentrations was by dividing the peak height derived from sample using the A/D software by the calculated slope of the standard curve. Variations in the slope of the standard curve during a day's run were corrected by the following procedure.</p><p>The change in the value of the slope of the standard curve between each run of standards was divided by the number of samples run between those standards to provide a calculated value for the slope of the standard curve at the point each sample was run. The value of the peak height for each sample was then recalculated by the estimated ratio of the standard curve slope at the point that sample was run. The estimate of the slope at each sample run is calculated by: (Initial slope + (incremental change per sample X # of samples run since initial standard was run)). The sample concentration is then calculated from the initial standard curve slope.</p><p><strong>Data correction with shore-based ICPMS data</strong><br />Shipboard determined dissolved Fe and Mn have been corrected using the shore-based ICPMS data that was measured by co-PI Dr. Jingfeng Wu. That data will be submitted separately. The corrected FIA data was calculated using the slope and the intercept of the correlation plot between the ICPMS data and FIA data on each of the days the FIA was run.</p><p><strong>Shipboard dissolved Fe:</strong> <strong>Shipboard calculation:</strong><br />The Fe concentration of samples was determined by dividing the sample peak height by the slope of the Fe standard solution. The standard curve was produced by adding +0 µL (+0 nM), +100 µL (+1.01 nM), +200 µL (+2.02 nM) of the shipboard standard solution into 200mL aliquots of seawater. This seawater was obtained from a 1L sample of seawater (usually from near the chlorophyll max) that had been filtered through a 0.2 µm pore-size Acropack cartridge, acidified with 1 ml of 6N HCl (sub boiling distilled) and microwaved to achieve a temperature of 60 + 10°C. A typical standard curve is shown in Figure 1 below.<br />&nbsp;<br />Figure 1. Fe standard curve from the standard addition method. (click on the image to view a larger version) <!-- height="374" --><br /><a href="http://bcodata.whoi.edu/US_GEOTRACES/AtlanticSection/CMeasures_Hatta/GT10_Figure1.png" target="_blank"><img alt="" src="http://bcodata.whoi.edu/US_GEOTRACES/AtlanticSection/CMeasures_Hatta/GT10_Figure1.png" style="width:519px" /></a><br />The shipboard standard solution was 2.020 µM and had been prepared by gravimmetric dilution from a high purity standard solution (1000 µg/mL) at the shore-based laboratory of University of Hawaii. Overall precision is 3.1%, and the average detection limit is 0.064 nM.</p>

gmd:credit.gmx:Anchor: Funding provided by NSF Ocean Sciences (NSF OCE) Award Number: OCE-0928741 Award URL: http://nsf.gov/awardsearch/showAward?AWD_ID=0928741

gmd:deliveryPoint.gco:CharacterString: Department of Oceanography, University of Hawai`i at Manoa 1000 Pope Road, MSB 512

gmd:keyword.gmx:Anchor: Flow injection lumogallion system with fluorometer
Flow injection lumogallion system with fluorometer

gmd:otherConstraints.gco:CharacterString: Access Constraints: none. Use Constraints: Please follow guidelines at: http://www.bco-dmo.org/terms-use Distribution liability: Under no circumstances shall BCO-DMO be liable for any direct, incidental, special, consequential, indirect, or punitive damages that result from the use of, or the inability to use, the materials in this data submission. If you are dissatisfied with any materials in this data submission your sole and exclusive remedy is to discontinue use.

gmd:description.gco:CharacterString: GEOTRACES is a SCOR sponsored program; and funding for program infrastructure development is provided by the U.S. National Science Foundation.GEOTRACES gained momentum following a special symposium, S02: Biogeochemical cycling of trace elements and isotopes in the ocean and applications to constrain contemporary marine processes (GEOSECS II), at a 2003 Goldschmidt meeting convened in Japan. The GEOSECS II acronym referred to the Geochemical Ocean Section Studies To determine full water column distributions of selected trace elements and isotopes, including their concentration, chemical speciation, and physical form, along a sufficient number of sections in each ocean basin to establish the principal relationships between these distributions and with more traditional hydrographic parameters;* To evaluate the sources, sinks, and internal cycling of these species and thereby characterize more completely the physical, chemical and biological processes regulating their distributions, and the sensitivity of these processes to global change; and* To understand the processes that control the concentrations of geochemical species used for proxies of the past environment, both in the water column and in the substrates that reflect the water column.GEOTRACES will be global in scope, consisting of ocean sections complemented by regional process studies. Sections and process studies will combine fieldwork, laboratory experiments and modelling. Beyond realizing the scientific objectives identified above, a natural outcome of this work will be to build a community of marine scientists who understand the processes regulating trace element cycles sufficiently well to exploit this knowledge reliably in future interdisciplinary studies.

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: BCO-DMO catalogue of parameters from GT10 - FIA-AlFe from the U.S. GEOTRACES NAT project of the U.S. GEOTRACES program

gmd:organisationName.gmx:Anchor: Biological and Chemical Oceanography Data Management Office (BCO-DMO)

gmd:contactInstructions.gco:CharacterString: For questions regarding this resource, please contact BCO-DMO via the email address provided.

gmd:otherCitationDetails.gco:CharacterString: http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/31385.rdf Name: cruise_id Units: text Description: Official cruise identifier e.g. KN199-04 = R/V Knorr cruise number 199-04. http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/31386.rdf Name: station Units: unitless Description: Station identifier; provided in original data submission. http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/31387.rdf Name: lon_360 Units: decimal degrees Description: Longitude ranging from 0 to 360 degrees. http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/31388.rdf Name: lon Units: decimal degrees Description: Longitude ranging from 0 to +/- 180. Negative values = West. Added by BCO-DMO based on lon_360. http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/31389.rdf Name: lat Units: decimal degrees Description: Latitude ranging from 0 to +/- 180. Positive values = North. http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/31390.rdf Name: cast_GEOTRC Units: unitless Description: Cast identifier, numbered consecutively within a station. PI-supplied values were identical to those in the intermediate US GEOTRACES master file. Originally submitted as 'CAST No.', this parameter name has been changed to conform to BCO-DMO's GEOTRACES naming conventions. http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/31391.rdf Name: depth_w Units: meters Description: Bottom depth from the log sheet during each cast. http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/31392.rdf Name: sample_bottle_GEOTRC Units: unitless Description: Unique identification numbers given to samples taken from bottles; rangies from 1 to 24; often used synonymously with bottle number. PI-supplied values were identical to those in the intermediate US GEOTRACES master file. Originally submitted as 'GO-Flo No.', this parameter name has been changed to conform to BCO-DMO's GEOTRACES naming conventions. http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/31393.rdf Name: sample_GEOTRC Units: unitless Description: Unique identifying number for US GEOTRACES samples; ranges from 5033 to 6078 for KN199-04 and from 6112 to 8148 for KN204-01. PI-supplied values were identical to those in the intermediate US GEOTRACES master file. Originally submitted as 'GEO Sample No.', this parameter name has been changed to conform to BCO-DMO's GEOTRACES naming conventions. http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/31394.rdf Name: press Units: db Description: Pressure in decibars. http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/31395.rdf Name: Al Units: nM Description: Dissolved aluminum concentration. http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/31396.rdf Name: Al_flag Units: unitless Description: Quality flag for Al. 2 = good; 3 = questionable; 4 = bad; 9 = missing data. http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/31397.rdf Name: Fe Units: nM Description: Dissolved iron concentration. (lt = 'less than') http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/31398.rdf Name: Fe_flag Units: unitless Description: Quality flag for Fe. 2 = good; 3 = questionable; 4 = bad; 9 = missing data. http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/31563.rdf Name: cruise_name Units: text Description: GEOTRACES cruise identifier. http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/33115.rdf Name: depth_GEOTRC_CTD Units: meters Description: Observation/sample depth in meters; calculated from CTD pressure. PI-supplied values were identical to those in the intermediate US GEOTRACES master file. Originally submitted as 'Depth [m]', this parameter name has been changed to conform to BCO-DMO's GEOTRACES naming conventions. http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/33116.rdf Name: event_GEOTRC Units: dimensionless Description: Unique identifying number for US GEOTRACES sampling events; ranges from 2001 to 2225 for KN199-04 events and from 3001 to 3282 for KN204-01 events. Values were added from the intermediate US GEOTRACES master file (see Processing Description). http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/33117.rdf Name: bottle_GEOTRC Units: dimensionless Description: Alphanumeric characters identifying bottle type (e.g. NIS representing Niskin and GF representing GOFLO) and position on a CTD rosette. Values were added from the intermediate US GEOTRACES master file (see Processing Description). http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/33118.rdf Name: BTL_ISO_DateTime_UTC Units: YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SS[.xx][+/-TZ] Description: Date and time (UTC) variable recorded at the bottle sampling time in ISO compliant format. Values were added from the intermediate US GEOTRACES master file (see Processing Description). This standard is based on ISO 8601:2004(E) and takes on the following form: 2009-08-30T14:05:00[.xx]Z (UTC time) http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/33119.rdf Name: station_GEOTRC Units: unitless Description: GEOTRACES station number; ranges from 1 through 12 for KN199-04 and 1 through 24 for KN204-01. Stations 7 and 9 were skipped on KN204-01. Some GeoFish stations are denoted as X_to_Y indicating the tow occurred between stations X and Y. Values were added from the intermediate US GEOTRACES master file (see Processing Description).

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: GB/NERC/BODC > British Oceanographic Data Centre, Natural Environment Research Council, United Kingdom

gmd:citedResponsibleParty.xlink:title: GB/NERC/BODC > British Oceanographic Data Centre, Natural Environment Research Council, United Kingdom

gmd:otherCitationDetails.gco:CharacterString: http://vocab.nerc.ac.uk/collection/P09/current/LONX/ Name: LONGITUDE Description: The angular distance east or west east or west of Greenwich to the point of interest. http://vocab.nerc.ac.uk/collection/P09/current/LATX/ Name: LATITUDE Description: The angular distance north or south from the equator, measured along the meridian of the point of interest. http://vocab.nerc.ac.uk/collection/P02/current/ACYC/ Name: Reference numbers Description: Data record, event, sample or measurement reference numbers http://vocab.nerc.ac.uk/collection/P01/current/PRESPR01/ Name: Pressure (spatial co-ordinate) exerted by the water body by profiling pressure sensor and corrected to read zero at sea level Description: The force per unit area exerted by the water column on a mobile sensor located in the water column. http://vocab.nerc.ac.uk/collection/P03/current/C035/ Name: Metal and metalloid concentrations Description: Parameters pertaining to metal and trace metalloid (i.e. excluding Si) concentrations in any material. http://vocab.nerc.ac.uk/collection/P03/current/C035/ Name: Metal and metalloid concentrations Description: Parameters pertaining to metal and trace metalloid (i.e. excluding Si) concentrations in any material. http://vocab.nerc.ac.uk/collection/P09/current/DEPH/ Name: DEPTH BELOW SEA SURFACE Description: The distance of a sensor or sampling point below the sea surface. http://vocab.nerc.ac.uk/collection/P01/current/DTUT8601/ Name: Date and time (UT in ISO8601 format to sub-second precision) Description: String corresponding to format 'yyyy-mm-ddThh:mi:ss.sss' optionally terminated by 'Z'

gmd:descriptor.gco:CharacterString: PI-supplied Description: Official cruise identifier e.g. KN199-04 = R/V Knorr cruise number 199-04.; General Description: cruise designation; name
PI-supplied Description: Station identifier; provided in original data submission.; General Description: consecutive station number

PI-supplied Description: Longitude ranging from 0 to 360 degrees.; General Description: longitude ranging from 0 to 360 degrees; especially useful for data collected during sampling transects that cross the dateline

PI-supplied Description: Longitude ranging from 0 to +/- 180. Negative values = West. Added by BCO-DMO based on lon_360.; General Description: longitude, in decimal degrees, East is positive, negative denotes West; Reported in some datsets as degrees, minutes NERC Description: The angular distance east or west east or west of Greenwich to the point of interest.

PI-supplied Description: Latitude ranging from 0 to +/- 180. Positive values = North.; General Description: latitude, in decimal degrees, North is positive, negative denotes South; Reported in some datasets as degrees, minutes NERC Description: The angular distance north or south from the equator, measured along the meridian of the point of interest.

PI-supplied Description: Cast identifier, numbered consecutively within a station. PI-supplied values were identical to those in the intermediate US GEOTRACES master file. Originally submitted as 'CAST No.', this parameter name has been changed to conform to BCO-DMO's GEOTRACES naming conventions.; General Description: cast or profile number
PI-supplied Description: Bottom depth from the log sheet during each cast.; General Description: bottom depth

PI-supplied Description: Unique identification numbers given to samples taken from bottles; rangies from 1 to 24; often used synonymously with bottle number. PI-supplied values were identical to those in the intermediate US GEOTRACES master file. Originally submitted as 'GO-Flo No.', this parameter name has been changed to conform to BCO-DMO's GEOTRACES naming conventions.; General Description: Niskin sample bottle number

PI-supplied Description: Unique identifying number for US GEOTRACES samples; ranges from 5033 to 6078 for KN199-04 and from 6112 to 8148 for KN204-01. PI-supplied values were identical to those in the intermediate US GEOTRACES master file. Originally submitted as 'GEO Sample No.', this parameter name has been changed to conform to BCO-DMO's GEOTRACES naming conventions.; General Description: unique sample identification or number; any combination of alpha numeric characters; precise definition is file dependent NERC Description: Data record, event, sample or measurement reference numbers

gco:attributeType.xlink:title: Pressure (spatial co-ordinate) exerted by the water body by profiling pressure sensor and corrected to read zero at sea level

gmd:descriptor.gco:CharacterString: PI-supplied Description: Pressure in decibars.; General Description: water pressure at measurement; depth reported as pressure; positive number increasing with water depth NERC Description: The force per unit area exerted by the water column on a mobile sensor located in the water column.

PI-supplied Description: Dissolved aluminum concentration.; General Description: Concentration of a trace metal in seawater. Refer to dataset for element name and units. NERC Description: Parameters pertaining to metal and trace metalloid (i.e. excluding Si) concentrations in any material.

PI-supplied Description: Quality flag for Al. 2 = good; 3 = questionable; 4 = bad; 9 = missing data.; General Description: quality flag; based on a PI established code; identifies a problem/quality issue with sample(s) from a given water bottle or single observation

PI-supplied Description: Dissolved iron concentration. (lt = 'less than'); General Description: Concentration of a trace metal in seawater. Refer to dataset for element name and units. NERC Description: Parameters pertaining to metal and trace metalloid (i.e. excluding Si) concentrations in any material.

PI-supplied Description: Quality flag for Fe. 2 = good; 3 = questionable; 4 = bad; 9 = missing data.; General Description: quality flag; based on a PI established code; identifies a problem/quality issue with sample(s) from a given water bottle or single observation

PI-supplied Description: GEOTRACES cruise identifier.; General Description: The cruise_name is a local name chosen by project investigators for a research expedition on a vessel, as opposed to the formal/official cruise ID asserted by the vessel operator.

PI-supplied Description: Observation/sample depth in meters; calculated from CTD pressure. PI-supplied values were identical to those in the intermediate US GEOTRACES master file. Originally submitted as 'Depth [m]', this parameter name has been changed to conform to BCO-DMO's GEOTRACES naming conventions.; General Description: observation/sample depth, in meters; best estimate; usually but not always calculated from pressure; calculated either from CTD pressure using Fofonoff and Millard (1982; UNESCO Tech Paper #44) algorithm adjusted for 1980 equation of state for seawater (EOS80) or simply equivalent to nominal depth as recorded during sampling if CTD pressure was unavailable NERC Description: The distance of a sensor or sampling point below the sea surface.

PI-supplied Description: Unique identifying number for US GEOTRACES sampling events; ranges from 2001 to 2225 for KN199-04 events and from 3001 to 3282 for KN204-01 events. Values were added from the intermediate US GEOTRACES master file (see Processing Description).; General Description: event or operation number; often derived from date/time (MMDDHHmm) of sampling and when combined with year (YYYY) is a unique sampling identifier/data processing key. Date/time is not necessarily in GMT.

PI-supplied Description: Alphanumeric characters identifying bottle type (e.g. NIS representing Niskin and GF representing GOFLO) and position on a CTD rosette. Values were added from the intermediate US GEOTRACES master file (see Processing Description).; General Description: water bottle number, generally assigned to a position on a CTD rosette, identifies all samples drawn from a given bottle

gco:attributeType.xlink:title: Date and time (UT in ISO8601 format to sub-second precision)

gmd:descriptor.gco:CharacterString: PI-supplied Description: Date and time (UTC) variable recorded at the bottle sampling time in ISO compliant format. Values were added from the intermediate US GEOTRACES master file (see Processing Description). This standard is based on ISO 8601:2004(E) and takes on the following form: 2009-08-30T14:05:00[.xx]Z (UTC time); General Description: Date/Time (UTC) ISO formattedThis standard is based on ISO 8601:2004(E) and takes on any of the following forms:2009-08-30T09:05:00[.xx] (local time)2009-08-30T14:05:00[.xx]Z (UTC time)2009-08-30T14:05:00[.xx]-05:00The dashes and the colons can be dropped.The T can also be dropped "by mutual agreement", but one needs the trailing Z if the time is UTC.Sample ISO_datetime_utc:2009-08-30T14:05:00[.xx]Z (UTC time)Format: YYYY-mm-ddTHH:MM:SS[.xx]Z (UTC time) NERC Description: String corresponding to format 'yyyy-mm-ddThh:mi:ss.sss' optionally terminated by 'Z'

PI-supplied Description: GEOTRACES station number; ranges from 1 through 12 for KN199-04 and 1 through 24 for KN204-01. Stations 7 and 9 were skipped on KN204-01. Some GeoFish stations are denoted as X_to_Y indicating the tow occurred between stations X and Y. Values were added from the intermediate US GEOTRACES master file (see Processing Description).; General Description: consecutive station number

gmd:organisationName.gmx:Anchor: Biological and Chemical Oceanography Data Management Office (BCO-DMO)

gmd:description.gco:CharacterString: <p><strong>Sampling Methods</strong><br />The samples (with the exception of surface samples) were collected for trace metal determinations at 11 stations from the RV Knorr using a custom-built US GEOTRACES trace metal clean rosette consisting of an epoxy painted Al rosette frame containing 24x12 L GO-FLO bottles (Cutter and Bruland, 2012). Immediately after the package was recovered, the tops of the GO-FLO bottles were covered with plastic bags and the bottles were removed from the frame and carried into the US GEOTRACES clean van for sub-sampling. The GO-FLO bottles were pressurized to 10 psi using 0.2 µm-filtered compressed air and samples were filtered through 0.2 µm Acropak filters. All sub-sampling was undertaken in the clean van using rigorous trace metal protocols. Surface samples are from the towed fish surface sampling system.</p><p><strong>Analytical Methods</strong><br /><strong>FIA Sample Preparation</strong>: Samples were drawn into pre-numbered 125 ml PMP bottles after three rinses and were stored in plastic bags in the dark at room temperature before determination which was usually within 12 -36 hours of collection. Prior to determination samples were acidified by the addition of 125 ul sub-boiling distilled 6N HCl (hereinafter 6N HCl) and were microwaved in groups of 4 for 3 minutes in a 900 W microwave oven to achieve a temperature of 60+10 °C. Samples were allowed to cool for at least 1 hour prior to determination. Samples were determined in groups of 8.</p><p><strong>FIA Standards</strong>: Shipboard mixed standards (Al and Fe, Mn) were prepared in the shore-based laboratory by serial dilution of commercial Al, Fe, and Mn standards (BDH Aristar) into distilled water which was acidified with the equivalent of 4 ml sub-boiled 6N HCl.&nbsp; Standards for instrument calibration were prepared daily from filtered seawater by acidifying 1 L of low Fe seawater from a previous cast with 1 ml of 6N HCl and microwaving for 5 minutes to reach a temperature of 60 + 10°C.&nbsp; After 1 hour, 200 + 2 ml of the cooled seawater was added to each of three 250 ml PMP bottles each of which had been rinsed three times with the microwaved seawater and shaken dry. Working standards were prepared by adding 0, +100µL, +200µL spikes of the shipboard mixed standard to these bottles, to yield a standard curve of +28.4nM and +56.81nM for Al, +1.26nM and +2.53nM for Fe, +5.11nM and +10.22nM for Mn. The system blank from the addition of the acid and buffer to samples was determined by double spiking a replicate sample i.e. by adding 2 x 125 ul 6N HCl and 5 ml of sample buffer to the replicate bottle and comparing the resulting signal to the original sample.</p><p><strong>Dissolved Al Concentrations</strong>: Dissolved Al was determined using a Flow Injection Analysis scheme with fluorometric detection. Major components were a Rabbit peristaltic pump, a Dynamax FL-1 fluorometer, a Rainin A/D board and a Macintosh G3 computer running Rainin MacIntegrator v 1.4.3 to log and reduce data. The analytical scheme produces a complex between lumogallion and dissolved Al which when excited at 484 nm produces fluorescence at 552 nm.&nbsp; Detailed description of the methodology is published in Resing and Measures (1994).</p><p>A 3-minute pre-concentration of sample (~9 ml) onto an 8-hydroxyquinoline (8-HQ) resin column yielded a detection limit of 1.02 and a precision of 1.94% at 17.58 nM.</p><p><strong>Dissolved Fe</strong>: Dissolved Fe was determined using a Flow Injection Analysis scheme with spectrophotometric detection (Rainin Dynamax UV-C). Major components were a Rabbit peristaltic pump, a Dynamax FL-1 fluorometer, a Rainin A/D board and a Macintosh G3 computer running Rainin MacIntegrator v 1.4.3 to log and reduce data. The spectrophotometric detection of the iron eluted from the column is achieved through its catalytic effect on the oxidation of N,N-dimethylp-phenylenediamine dihydrochloride (DPD) the oxidised product is measured at 514 nm. Detailed description of the methodology is published in Measures et al (1995).</p><p>A 3-minute pre-concentration of sample (~9 ml) onto an 8-hydroxyquinoline (8-HQ) resin column yielded a detection limit of 0.064 nM and a precision of 3.1%.</p><p><strong>Calculation of FIA data</strong>: Calculation of sample concentrations was by dividing the peak height derived from sample using the A/D software by the calculated slope of the standard curve. Variations in the slope of the standard curve during a day's run were corrected by the following procedure.</p><p>The change in the value of the slope of the standard curve between each run of standards was divided by the number of samples run between those standards to provide a calculated value for the slope of the standard curve at the point each sample was run. The value of the peak height for each sample was then recalculated by the estimated ratio of the standard curve slope at the point that sample was run. The estimate of the slope at each sample run is calculated by: (Initial slope + (incremental change per sample X # of samples run since initial standard was run)). The sample concentration is then calculated from the initial standard curve slope.</p><p><strong>Data correction with shore-based ICPMS data</strong><br />Shipboard determined dissolved Fe and Mn have been corrected using the shore-based ICPMS data that was measured by co-PI Dr. Jingfeng Wu. That data will be submitted separately. The corrected FIA data was calculated using the slope and the intercept of the correlation plot between the ICPMS data and FIA data on each of the days the FIA was run.</p><p><strong>Shipboard dissolved Fe:</strong> <strong>Shipboard calculation:</strong><br />The Fe concentration of samples was determined by dividing the sample peak height by the slope of the Fe standard solution. The standard curve was produced by adding +0 µL (+0 nM), +100 µL (+1.01 nM), +200 µL (+2.02 nM) of the shipboard standard solution into 200mL aliquots of seawater. This seawater was obtained from a 1L sample of seawater (usually from near the chlorophyll max) that had been filtered through a 0.2 µm pore-size Acropack cartridge, acidified with 1 ml of 6N HCl (sub boiling distilled) and microwaved to achieve a temperature of 60 + 10°C. A typical standard curve is shown in Figure 1 below.<br />&nbsp;<br />Figure 1. Fe standard curve from the standard addition method. (click on the image to view a larger version) <!-- height="374" --><br /><a href="http://bcodata.whoi.edu/US_GEOTRACES/AtlanticSection/CMeasures_Hatta/GT10_Figure1.png" target="_blank"><img alt="" src="http://bcodata.whoi.edu/US_GEOTRACES/AtlanticSection/CMeasures_Hatta/GT10_Figure1.png" style="width:519px" /></a><br />The shipboard standard solution was 2.020 µM and had been prepared by gravimmetric dilution from a high purity standard solution (1000 µg/mL) at the shore-based laboratory of University of Hawaii. Overall precision is 3.1%, and the average detection limit is 0.064 nM.</p>

<p><strong>B</strong><strong>lank calculation:</strong><br />At sea, the blank calculation of the data was made using the value derived from a sample that had been spiked with EDTA. This process yields a sample that should have no uncomplexed Fe thus allowing subtraction of the system blank.<br /><br />Shore based adjustment of the shipboard data was made by comparison with the shore-based ICP MS data measured by J. Wu at U Miami. A plot of each station's data (FIA vs ICP MS) yielded a slope and intercept that was then used to recalculate the shipboard data. This indicated that the shipboard blank correction was underestimating the system blank.<br /><br />Table: Slope and intercept between shipboard FIA (substituted EDTA blank) and ICPMS data<br /><strong>Station&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Slope&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Intercept&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; R2</strong><br />USGT10-01&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 0.930&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 0.635&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 0.670<br />USGT10-03&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp; 0.644&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 0.316&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 0.868<br />USGT10-05&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp; 0.807&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 0.383&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 0.908<br />USGT10-06&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 0.930&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 0.112&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 0.910<br />USGT10-07&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 0.930&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 0.112&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp; 0.910<br />USGT10-09&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1.183&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 0.051&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 0.909<br />USGT10-10&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1.208&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 0.057&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp; 0.857<br />USGT10-11&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1.150&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 0.091&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 0.863<br />USGT10-12&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp; 1.281&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 0.191&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 0.947<br /><br />The ICPMS data reported by Miami (Dr. Wu) were only for full depth stations. One of the demi stations were determined at sea on the same day that full depth stations were run specifically GT10-06 and GT 10-07. Thus, these samples were adjusted using the same slope and intercept used for the full depth station. However, the other demi station samples were determined on separate days. Thus, the samples cannot currently be adjusted with existing ICPMS data.<br /><br />The following demi stations have not been adjusted and are not reported: USGT10-02, USGT10-08.</p><p><strong>Quality flags</strong><br />Data have been flagged using the WOCE system of flags. Good is 2. Questionable is 3. Bad is 4. Samples that appear to be contaminated have been flagged 3.<br /><br />Determination of contamination was by agreement with ICP MS data after adjustment (see above).<br /><br />For dissolved Fe, samples in which both the ICP MS and the FIA data appear to be bad (not oceanographically consistent) have been flagged 4.<br /><br /><strong>Flagged data from GT10 (2010 cruise):</strong><br />Total reported sample count: 211<br />Flag 2 (Good): 175<br />Flag 3 (Questionable): 49<br />Flag 4 (Bad): 7</p><p><strong>Accuracy results:</strong><br />There are no shipboard results for the recoveries of Certified Reference Materials (CRMs) or consensus reference materials (e.g., SAFe water) as these samples are too acid to be run using this protocol. Instead these data are corrected using the shore-based ICP MS values which are calibrated against SaFe samples.</p><p><strong>BCO-DMO Processing Notes</strong><br />- Parameter names were modified to conform with BCO-DMO conventions.<br />- '-999' values were replaced with 'nd' to indicate 'no data'.<br />- The 'lon' parameter was calculated using the 'lon_360' values provided in the original data submission. (lon = lon_360 - 360).<br />- Original data submission received on 12/18/12 was replaced with updated data received on 12/21/12, in which a small error and quality flags have been corrected.<br />- Dataset updated to new version on 22 May 2013.<br />- The dataset was again updated to a newer version (including updates and error fixes) on 14 October 2013 (most recent version).</p><p><strong>Additional GEOTRACES Processing:</strong><br />After the data were submitted to the International Data Management Office, BODC, the office noticed that important identifying information was missing in many datasets. With the agreement of BODC and the US GEOTRACES lead PIs, BCO-DMO added standard US GEOTRACES information, such as the US GEOTRACES event number, to each submitted dataset lacking this information. To accomplish this, BCO-DMO compiled a 'master' dataset composed of the following parameters: station_GEOTRC, cast_GEOTRC (bottle and pump data only), event_GEOTRC, sample_GEOTRC, sample_bottle_GEOTRC (bottle data only), bottle_GEOTRC (bottle data only), depth_GEOTRC_CTD (bottle data only), depth_GEOTRC_CTD_rounded (bottle data only), BTL_ISO_DateTime_UTC (bottle data only), and GeoFish_id (GeoFish data only). This added information will facilitate subsequent analysis and inter comparison of the datasets.<br /><br />Bottle parameters in the master file were taken from the GT-C_Bottle_GT10, GT-C_Bottle_GT11, ODF_Bottle_GT10, and ODF_Bottle_GT11 datasets. Non-bottle parameters, including those from GeoFish tows, Aerosol sampling, and McLane Pumps, were taken from the Event_Log_GT10 and Event_Log_GT11 datasets. McLane pump cast numbers missing in event logs were taken from the Particulate Th-234 dataset submitted by Ken Buesseler.<br /><br />A standardized BCO-DMO method (called "join") was then used to merge the missing parameters to each US GEOTRACES dataset, most often by matching on sample_GEOTRC or on some unique combination of other parameters.<br /><br />If the master parameters were included in the original data file and the values did not differ from the master file, the original data columns were retained and the names of the parameters were changed from the PI-submitted names to the standardized master names. If there were differences between the PI-supplied parameter values and those in the master file, both columns were retained. If the original data submission included all of the master parameters, no additional columns were added, but parameter names were modified to match the naming conventions of the master file.<br /><br />See the dataset parameters documentation for a description of which parameters were supplied by the PI and which were added via the join method.</p>

gmd:organisationName.gmx:Anchor: Biological and Chemical Oceanography Data Management Office (BCO-DMO)

gmd:contactInstructions.gco:CharacterString: For questions regarding this resource, please contact BCO-DMO via the email address provided.

gmi:description.gco:CharacterString: PI Supplied Instrument Name: GO-FLO Bottle PI Supplied Instrument Description:Samples were collected using a custom-built US GEOTRACES trace metal clean rosette consisting of an epoxy painted Al rosette frame containing 24x12 L GO-FLO bottles. Instrument Name: GO-FLO Bottle Instrument Short Name:GO-FLO Instrument Description: GO-FLO bottle cast used to collect water samples for pigment, nutrient, plankton, etc. The GO-FLO sampling bottle is specially designed to avoid sample contamination at the surface, internal spring contamination, loss of sample on deck (internal seals), and exchange of water from different depths. Community Standard Description: http://vocab.nerc.ac.uk/collection/L05/current/30/

PI Supplied Instrument Name: GeoFish PI Supplied Instrument Description:Surface samples are from the towed fish surface sampling system. Instrument Name: GeoFish Towed near-Surface Sampler Instrument Short Name:GeoFish Instrument Description: The GeoFish towed sampler is a custom designed near surface (<2m) sampling system for the collection of trace metal clean seawater. It consists of a PVC encapsulated lead weighted torpedo and separate PVC depressor vane supporting the intake utilizing all PFA Teflon tubing connected to a deck mounted, air-driven, PFA Teflon dual-diaphragm pump which provides trace-metal clean seawater at up to 3.7L/min. The GeoFish is towed at up to 13kts off to the side of the vessel outside of the ship's wake to avoid possible contamination from the ship's hull. It was developed by Geoffrey Smith and Ken Bruland (University of California, Santa Cruz). Community Standard Description: http://vocab.nerc.ac.uk/collection/L05/current/31/

PI Supplied Instrument Name: Flow Injection Analyzer PI Supplied Instrument Description:Dissolved Fe was determined using a Flow Injection Analysis scheme with spectrophometric detection (Rainin Dynamax UV-C). Major components of the scheme include a Rabbit peristaltic pump, a Dynamax FL-1 fluorometer, a Rainin A/D board, and a Macintosh G3 computer running Rainin MacIntegrator v 1.4.3 to log and reduce data. Instrument Name: Flow Injection Analyzer Instrument Short Name:FIA Instrument Description: An instrument that performs flow injection analysis. Flow injection analysis (FIA) is an approach to chemical analysis that is accomplished by injecting a plug of sample into a flowing carrier stream. FIA is an automated method in which a sample is injected into a continuous flow of a carrier solution that mixes with other continuously flowing solutions before reaching a detector. Precision is dramatically increased when FIA is used instead of manual injections and as a result very specific FIA systems have been developed for a wide array of analytical techniques. Community Standard Description: http://vocab.nerc.ac.uk/collection/L05/current/LAB36/

gmx:Anchor.xlink:title: Flow injection lumogallion system with fluorometer

gmd:code.gmx:Anchor: Flow injection lumogallion system with fluorometer

gmi:type.gco:CharacterString: Flow injection lumogallion system with fluorometer

gmi:description.gco:CharacterString: PI Supplied Instrument Name: Flow injection lumogallion system with fluorometer PI Supplied Instrument Description:Dissolved Al was determined using a Flow Injection Analysis scheme with fluorometeric detection. The scheme produces a complex between lumogallion and dissolved Al. Major components of the scheme include a Rabbit peristaltic pump, a Dynamax FL-1 fluorometer, a Rainin A/D board, and a Macintosh G3 computer running Rainin MacIntegrator v 1.4.3 to log and reduce data. Instrument Name: Flow injection lumogallion system with fluorometer Instrument Short Name:FIA with Fluorometer Instrument Description: An analytical system used to determine concentrations of chemical species in a sample based on the fluorescence from the reaction between lumogallion and the species of interest. The system typically comprises individual components typically including pumps, injection and autosampler valves, preconcentration columns and a fluorometer. The system is normally uniquely assembled for each analysis.(From SeaDataNet) Community Standard Description: http://vocab.nerc.ac.uk/collection/L22/current/TOOL0513/

gmd:title.gmx:Anchor: International Council for the Exploration of the Sea
